examples.text: Don't look so angry.
There's no need to worry so.
Why has it taken **so long**?
That wasn't **so bad**, was it?
She spoke so quietly (that) I could hardly hear her.
What is it that's **so important** it can't wait five minutes?
He was so impressed that he jumped up and down with excitement.
She gets so caught up in her fame that she neglects her true friends.
It was so incredibly cheap it was unbelievable.
I'm not so stupid as to believe that.
**Would you be so kind as to** lock the door when you leave?
I'm so glad to see you.
The girls looked so pretty in their summer dresses.
I was pleased that **so many** people turned up.
We have **so much** to do.
It's **so good** to have you back.
We've worked **so hard** to get to this point.
They came **so close** to winning.
You're going to Harvard! That's **so great**!
Their attitude is **so very** English.
The article was **just so much** *(= nothing but)* nonsense.
I am so pleased with this new book.
He sat there **ever so** quietly.
I do love it so.
I haven't enjoyed myself so much for a long time.
I have never felt so humiliated in my entire life.
It wasn't so good as last time.
It's not so easy as you'd think.
He was not so quick a learner as his brother.
It's **not so much** a hobby **as** a career *(= more like a career than a hobby)*.
Off she went **without so much as** *(= without even)* a ‘goodbye’.

definitions.definition: used to show the size, amount or number of something

examples.text: The fish was about so big *(= said when using your hands to show the size)*.
There are **only so many** *(= only a limited number of)* hours in a day.

definitions.definition: used to refer back to something that has already been mentioned

examples.text: ‘Is he coming?’ ‘**I hope so**.’
‘Did they mind?’ ‘I **don't think so**.’
If she notices, she never **says so**.
I might be away next week. **If so**, I won't be able to see you.
We are very busy—**so much so that** we won't be able to take time off this year.
Programs are expensive, and **even more so** if you have to keep altering them.
I hear that you're a writer—**is that so** *(= is that true)*?
George is going to help me, or **so he says** *(= that is what he says but I am not sure if I believe him)*.
They asked me to call them and I **did so** *(= I called)*.
She leaked the story to the media and, **in so doing**, helped bring down the president.
He thinks I dislike him but that just isn't so.
Times have changed and **so have I**.
‘I prefer the first version.’ ‘**So do we**.’
Temperatures are rising in Canada, and **so too** are the annual blueberry harvests.

definitions.definition: used to agree that something is true, especially when you are surprised

examples.text: ‘You were there, too.’ ‘**So I was**—I'd forgotten.’
‘There's another one.’ ‘**So there is**.’

definitions.definition: used, often with a negative, before adjectives and noun phrases to emphasize something that you are saying

examples.text: He is **so not** the right person for you.
That is **so not** cool.

definitions.definition: used, especially by children, to say that what somebody says is not the case and the opposite is true

examples.text: ‘You're not telling the truth, are you?’ ‘I am, so!’

definitions.definition: used when you are showing somebody how to do something or telling them how something happened

examples.text: Stand with your arms out, so.
**So it was that** he finally returned home.

definitions.definition: used at the end of a list to show that it continues in the same way

examples.text: We discussed everything—when to go, what to see and so on.

definitions.definition: used to give an important extra reason why something is true

examples.text: His achievement is remarkable; all the more so because he had no help at all.

definitions.definition: used after a number, an amount, etc. to show that it is not exact

examples.text: There were twenty or so *(= about twenty)* people there.
We stayed for an hour or so.

definitions.definition: with the intention of doing something

examples.text: We went early so as to get good seats.

definitions.definition: used to show that you accept something and will not try to change it or cannot change it

examples.text: If he doesn't want to be involved, then so be it.

definitions.definition: used to show that you have finished talking about something

examples.text: So much for the situation in Germany. Now we turn our attention to France.

definitions.definition: used to suggest that something has not been successful or useful

examples.text: So much for that idea!
The programme has been so organized that none of the talks overlap.

wordOrigin: adverb Old English swā, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zo and German so.
